oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Holly Dunn Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Holly Dunn (performer), conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Holly Dunn; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie and Holly Dunn discuss the inspiration behind 'Are you ever going to love me' -- (00:47) Dunn discusses 'You're Still Keeping Me Up at Night' (01:30) Dunn and Collie Texas themes and name behind song/album: 'The Blue Rose of Texas' -- (2:57) Dunn discusses why she chose Dolly Parton's song 'Most of All, Why?' for a track -- (3:45) Dunn and Collie talk about Dolly Parton and her helpfulness in track recording -- (04:21) Dunn's 'Thunder and Lightning' is described with a 'Cajun feel" -- (5:32) Dunn speaks of "No One Takes a Train Anymore" written by Dunn's brother Chris and initially dismissed -- (08:00) Dunn discusses her time with the MTM record label and eventually change to Warner Brothers recording label -- (09:43) -- Collie and Dunn readdress change in record label -- (10:30) Dunn discusses time constraints for creating an album -- (12:41) Side Two of Dunn's 'The Blue Rose of Texas' is discussed -- (13:38) Dunn compares her 'Sometime Today' to classic stylings -- (14:47) Chris Waters' profile is discussed -- (15:33) Dunn discusses relationship with Waters -- (16:53) Dunn talks about why she doesn't accept tapes on the road -- (18:48) -- (14:21) 'There Goes My Heart Again' is the single discussed and the Buck Owen influences behind the song -- (19:52) Dunn and Collie jokes about helping the song writers of 'There's No Heart So Strong' (20:55) Dunn describes her family. Including her minister father and growing up in San Antonio -- (22:45) Dunn recalls the story behind 'Daddy's Hands' -- (25:45) Collie and Dunn discuss final thoughts
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Collie, Biff; Dunn, Holly;
